üìå THE PAINTING I INHERITED HAS A LABEL ON THE BACK DECLARING ITS AUTHENTICITY, IS THIS ENOUGH TO SELL IT? Those who are familiar with the art market know that the phenomenon of artist's archives is fairly recent, because until a few decades ago, works were often 'authenticated' simply with a label on the back signed either by the artist or the gallerist. In the event of a sale, is this still valid or is it necessary to get a new one? A distinction must be made: if the label on the back of the work is issued directly by the artist, who is still alive, it may be sufficient. If, on the other hand, the author of the work is not alive, it may be necessary to apply to the relevant archive (beware, however, of DIY) ‚ùå. Let us dispel a myth: there is no definitive certification of the authorship of a work. Therefore, even independent art experts can confirm or disavow the authorship of a work of art, despite the claims of an archive. Did you know? #wealthmanagement #heritage #artmarket

There is compelling evidence that a urinal ('Fountain') submitted to a New York sculpture exhibition in 1917 was the work of Elsa von Freytag-Loringhoven rather than Marcel Duchamp as long believed. It is an argument that began more than 20 years ago and has had at least one scholar combing through New England‚Äôs historic plumbing shop records. Von Freytag-Loringhoven was a fascinating figure and a committed member of the Dadaist movement. Even so, many would find it hard to give up Fountain‚Äôs Duchamp attribution. In this story from The Guardian, Julian Spalding, whose book Art Exposed will be released in November, says that the misattribution of Fountain ‚Äúmeans that the whole foundation stone of conceptual art just collapses. A work of art is not a work of art just because somebody says it is. This changes the history of art and has huge implications for the contemporary art market, and the millions that have been invested in it.‚Äù He argues that as a work by Von Freytag-Loringhoven it was more nuanced, with layers of meaning both personal and political. As a work by Duchamp, it was more of a joke, putting two fingers up to the art world establishment. I‚Äôm tempted to think that accepting a different meaning or authorship of this artwork would have no effect on the Contemporary market . If the public was ready to accept the death of art in the bowl of a urinal in 1917, it wouldn't matter who the ‚Äòmaker‚Äô was. Today it could remain a Von Freytag-Loringhoven original and a Duchampian joke. https://lnkd.in/emyduc2u

This painting titled 'Bacchus ‚Äì Iron curtain of the Vienna State Opera' by Cy Twombly (https://lnkd.in/dA5kwbgH) was sold for 42 million dollars. About the artist: "Late Mr. Twombly countered the Olympian loftiness of the Abstract Expressionists by stressing the loquacious, cosmopolitan nature of art and its connectedness not only to other forms of culture but also to the volatile machinations of the human mind and to lived experience. His art functioned as a kind of sieve in which he caught and brilliantly composed the chaotic flood of existing objects or images that the world offered. Mr. Twombly, always cerebral and introspective, isolated individual motifs like targets and flags, mystifying their familiarity with finely calibrated brushwork and collage. His methodical approach to art making helped set the stage for Conceptual Art and influenced generations of artists."
